content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Mia Bennett: Well, I was born in Little Rock, Arkansas, and I've always considered myself a Southern girl at heart. Growing up on Elm Street, I had a pretty typical childhood—nothing too dramatic, but full of small-town charm. My parents worked hard to make ends meet, and while we weren't rich, we had everything we needed. My dad worked at a local factory, and my mom was a part-time teacher at a community college. They both only made it through high school, but they always encouraged me to keep learning. I was the first in my family to graduate from high school, which felt like a big deal. After that, I took a gap year to figure out what I wanted to do with my life. I worked part-time at a bookstore and volunteered at a local food bank, which really opened my eyes to the challenges people face in our community. I eventually went to community college for a year, but I had to drop out to help my mom with some health issues. It was tough, but I kept pushing forward. Now, I'm working part-time at a café while I try to decide if I want to go back to school or explore other opportunities. Life hasn't always been easy, but I've learned to adapt and make the most of what I have.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Mia Bennett: Yeah, there was definitely a crossroads. Right after I finished high school, I had this opportunity to move to another state for a special scholarship program at a technical school. It was a chance to get some real hands-on training in something I was interested in—graphic design. But at the same time, my mom was diagnosed with a chronic illness, and my dad was struggling to keep up with the bills. I felt like I couldn't leave them behind. I remember sitting on the couch one night, staring at the scholarship letter, and just feeling torn. On one hand, I knew this could be my shot at something better, but on the other hand, I didn't want to abandon my family when they needed me most. In the end, I decided to stay. I took a job at the bookstore and started helping my mom with her appointments and medications. It was hard, but I realized that my family was my foundation. I didn't know it then, but that choice taught me the value of responsibility and sacrifice. It also made me more determined to find a way to support myself so I could eventually go back to school and make up for lost time. That moment really shaped who I am today—someone who puts family first, but also never stops dreaming about what could be.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Mia Bennett: I think it was a conscious choice, even if it didn't feel like it at the time. I remember weighing every option, talking to my parents, even crying over the decision. I didn't just 'fall into' staying—I made a deliberate decision to put my family first. But I also knew I couldn't stay stuck in that place forever. So I started setting little goals for myself, like saving up for a community college course or learning new skills on my own. It wasn't just about being responsible; it was about finding a balance between what I owed to my family and what I wanted for myself. I think that's what made it a real choice, not just something that 'happened' to me.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Mia Bennett: Absolutely, I think if I had reached out for help, things might have gone differently. There was a local nonprofit that offered assistance to families in need, and I remember seeing their flyers at the food bank where I volunteered. I didn't ask for help because I felt like I had to be strong for my parents, but looking back, I wish I had been more open to support. I think sometimes people like me—working-class, trying to do the right thing—feel like we have to handle everything on our own. But I've since learned that asking for help isn't a weakness. It's just smart. If I had known that, maybe I could have taken that scholarship opportunity and still found a way to support my mom. I guess I'm learning now that it's okay to lean on others, even if it doesn't feel natural at first.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Mia Bennett: Right now, I don't have a partner or children. My family is my main support system, and I'm really close to my parents, even though things have been tough. My mom is doing better now, thanks to some new treatments, and my dad has found a more stable job at the factory. We still live on Elm Street, though I've been thinking about moving somewhere a little closer to the city so I can have more opportunities for work and maybe even go back to school eventually. I don't see myself getting married anytime soon—I want to focus on building a solid future for myself first. But I do have a few close friends from high school who I keep in touch with, and we often meet up for coffee or go to local events. I think I'm still figuring out what I want in life, but I know I want to be someone who can support others, just like my parents did for me.

Going through those interview questions felt like revisiting the different chapters of my life, each one bringing back a mix of emotions and realizations. Talking about my childhood reminded me of the simplicity and strength of my roots in Little Rock, and how my parents' sacrifices shaped my values. Reflecting on that crossroads after high school was tough—it still feels like one of the hardest decisions I've ever made, but it also showed me who I am: someone who puts family first but never stops dreaming. I realized how much I've grown from that experience, even if I didn't take the path I initially wanted. When I thought about whether my choice was conscious or just something that happened, I saw how much intention went into my decision, even if it wasn't clear at the time. And when I considered if I could have used more help, I felt a mix of regret and hope—regret for not asking for support earlier, but hope that I can be better about it moving forward. Finally, talking about my family and future made me feel grounded, even as I continue to figure out what's next. I know I still have a long way to go, but I'm grateful for where I am and the people who have supported me along the way.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Mia Bennett: My immediate family is just my parents and me. We don't have any siblings, which was a bit unusual for our neighborhood, but my parents always said we were a small family with a lot of love. My grandmother on my dad's side still lives in a small town a few hours away, and we try to visit her whenever we can. She's pretty old now, but she's sharp as a tack and always has stories about growing up in the 50s. I used to love hearing her talk about the changes in the South over the years. We don't see each other as often as I'd like, but when we do, it's like time stands still. I think she sees me as her legacy in a way, and that means a lot to me. I hope to make her proud, even if I'm not sure what that looks like yet.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Mia Bennett: Outside of my family, my closest friends are from high school—some of us have stayed in touch, while others have drifted apart over the years. There's Sarah, who's a nurse now, and we still meet up for coffee or go to local concerts. She's been a huge support to me, especially during the tough times with my mom. Then there's Jake, who moved to Oklahoma after college and works in IT. We don't talk as much anymore, but I know he's always there if I need him. I also have a few coworkers at the café who I consider friends—people like Marcus, who's been working there longer than I have, and who's always got my back. I think the thing that connects all of them is that they've seen me at my most vulnerable, and they've still stuck around. I don't know if I'd be where I am today without them. They remind me that even in the smallest of places, like Little Rock, there are people who care and who believe in you, even when you don't believe in yourself.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Mia Bennett: I live in a pretty quiet neighborhood on Elm Street, which has always felt like home to me. It's one of those places where everyone knows each other, and there's a real sense of community. The houses are mostly older, with big front porches and lots of greenery. Some of the neighbors are retired, others are young families trying to make their way, and a few are like me—just trying to figure out what comes next. There's a small park at the end of the street where kids play and people like to sit and chat on nice days. I used to walk there every morning before work, just to clear my head. The café I work at is only a few blocks away, so I know every corner of the neighborhood pretty well. It's not glamorous, but there's something comforting about it. I've seen the same faces for years, and I think that's part of what keeps me rooted here. Even though I've thought about moving closer to the city for better opportunities, I don't know if I could leave this place behind. It's where I grew up, and it's where I learned the most about life, family, and what it means to persevere.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Mia Bennett: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. It's not the kind of neighborhood where you lock your doors at night or worry about strangers lurking around, but there's always a sense of watchfulness. People look out for each other in ways that you don't always see in bigger cities. If something's wrong, someone will know. I remember one time when my mom was really unwell, and a neighbor brought over a casserole without even being asked. That kind of thing happens here—small acts of kindness that make you feel like you're not alone. I think that's why I've never felt the need to leave. Safety here isn't about walls or locks; it's about the people and the trust we've built over the years. I can't imagine living somewhere where I didn't feel that connection.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Mia Bennett: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. The good thing is, I know this place inside and out. I know which streets are quiet at night, which shops have the best coffee, and which neighbors will always have a kind word or a spare cup of soup when you need it. But it's not without its challenges. Sometimes, I feel like I'm stuck in a loop—working the same job, seeing the same faces, and not really moving forward the way I want to. There are days when I get frustrated, wondering if I'll ever be able to do something more with my life. But then there are other days when I look around and realize how lucky I am to have this community, to have my family, and to still have hope. I think that's what keeps me going. It's not perfect, but it's real, and that matters more than anything.

Going through the interview questions about my family, neighborhood, and sense of safety brought up a lot of feelings I hadn't really thought about in a while. Talking about my family reminded me how much they've shaped who I am, and how much I still rely on them, even as I try to figure out my own path. When I described my neighborhood, I realized how much it means to me—not just because of the familiar streets or the park, but because of the people who live here. It's a place where I feel seen and supported, even on my hardest days. And when I thought about safety, I saw how different it is from the bigger cities I've only heard about. Here, safety isn't about locks or security systems—it's about trust, about knowing someone will have your back if you need them. I think that's why I haven't felt the need to leave, even when I've thought about it. This neighborhood, these people, and my family—they're my roots, and I'm starting to understand that sometimes, the most important things in life aren't about moving forward, but about staying grounded in what matters most.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Mia Bennett: A typical week for me is pretty consistent, but there are little variations depending on what's going on with my mom or if there's a big event in town. I usually wake up around 7 a.m., make a quick breakfast, and then head to the café where I work. My shifts are usually in the mornings, so I get off around noon and have a little bit of time to myself. I like to walk to the park or just sit on my porch and read a book or catch up on some online classes I've been taking on my own. After lunch, I might run some errands or help my mom with her medication schedule. In the afternoons, I sometimes volunteer at the food bank a few times a week, which is something I really enjoy—it reminds me of why I started this journey in the first place. On weekends, I like to spend time with friends or family, maybe go to a local concert or just have a quiet day at home. There's not much variety, but I've learned to find joy in the routine. It's not exciting, but it's steady, and that feels good right now.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Mia Bennett: I work part-time at a local café called 'The Daily Grind,' which is actually owned by an older couple who've been in the business for over thirty years. I work mornings, usually from 7 a.m. to noon, five days a week. The café is a cozy place with a lot of regulars—some of them are neighbors, others are just folks who pass through the area. I've gotten to know a lot of the regulars, and it's funny how some of them have become like extended family. My job is mostly barista work—making coffee, cleaning tables, and helping out with the counter. It's not glamorous, but I enjoy the rhythm of it. There's something comforting about the routine, and I feel like I'm part of something bigger than myself. Plus, the tips help out a lot, especially when my mom is having a tough month. I've been thinking about taking some online courses in graphic design on the side, just to keep my skills fresh and maybe open up new opportunities down the line. It's a small step, but it feels like progress.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Mia Bennett: Outside of work and helping my mom, I also have this little routine of writing in a journal every evening before bed. It started a few years ago when I was feeling really lost, and I needed a way to process everything. I write about my day, my thoughts, and sometimes even my worries about the future. It's not fancy—just a simple notebook I keep on my nightstand. I've filled up a few of them now, and looking back, I can see how much I've grown. It's become a way for me to stay grounded, especially when life feels overwhelming. I also try to set aside time a few times a week to explore new things, like taking a walk through the downtown area or checking out a new bookstore. It's not much, but it helps me feel like I'm still moving forward, even if it's just a little at a time.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Mia Bennett: Well, lately, I've started getting up a little earlier to go for a run before work. It's something I've been meaning to do for a while, but I always found excuses not to. Now that my mom is doing better, I feel like I have a little more space to take care of myself. I run along the river trail that's just a few miles from my house—it's peaceful there, and I can clear my head. It's not much, but it's a small way to take control of my own health and energy. I also started going to a community class on graphic design a few weeks ago, even though it's just online. It's been a bit of a challenge balancing it with work and everything else, but I'm enjoying learning again. I guess I'm trying to find little ways to push myself forward, even if it's just one step at a time.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Mia Bennett: I don't have children yet, but I've thought a lot about what it would be like if I did. I imagine a typical weekday during the school year would start early, with my kids getting up, having breakfast, and then heading off to school. I'd probably make sure they have everything they need for the day—lunch, backpacks, and maybe a little note to encourage them. After school, they might have some activities—maybe sports or art classes, or just hanging out with friends. I'd love to be involved in their lives, to help them with homework or just listen when they need to talk. I know it's a different kind of responsibility than what I have now, but I think I'd want to be the kind of parent who supports their dreams, just like my parents did for me. Right now, I'm still figuring out my own path, but I hope that one day, I can be a source of strength and encouragement for someone else's journey.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect on how much my neighborhood, family, and daily routines shape who I am. Talking about my family reminded me of how deeply they've influenced my values and decisions, especially that crossroads after high school. It's strange how something so difficult at the time now feels like a defining moment that taught me responsibility, sacrifice, and the importance of balance. When I described my neighborhood, I realized how much it means to me—not just because of the familiar streets, but because of the people who live here. It's a place where I feel seen and supported, even on my hardest days. I've always thought about moving closer to the city for better opportunities, but I've come to understand that sometimes the most important things in life aren't about moving forward, but about staying grounded in what matters most. My daily routine, with its small consistencies and quiet moments of growth, has become a source of comfort. Whether it's my job at the café, helping my mom, or writing in my journal, these things keep me steady. I've also started making small changes, like running in the mornings and taking online classes, which remind me that progress doesn't always have to be dramatic—it can be gradual, and still meaningful. I'm learning to appreciate the rhythm of my life, even when it feels repetitive, and to find hope in the little steps I take toward the future.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Mia Bennett: As for my health, I'd say I'm pretty average. I don't have any major medical issues, but I do struggle with stress from time to time, especially when things get overwhelming with work and taking care of my mom. I've started paying more attention to how I feel physically, though. I've been trying to eat better—more fruits and vegetables, less fast food—and I've been going for those morning runs to keep my energy up. I used to ignore my body's signals, thinking I could push through anything, but I've learned that taking care of myself is just as important as taking care of others. I also try to get enough sleep, though it's not always easy with the way my days can blur together. I've been seeing a counselor at the community center once a week, which has helped me process some of the heavier emotions I carry. It's not perfect, but I'm getting better at listening to my body and mind and giving them what they need.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Mia Bennett: What makes it easy to stay healthy, I think, is having that small routine I've built for myself—like the morning runs and the journaling at night. Those things give me a sense of control, even when everything else feels a bit out of my hands. But what makes it hard is the stress of balancing everything. Sometimes, I get so caught up in taking care of my mom or working long hours that I forget to take a break, or I skip a meal because I'm too tired. I also struggle with the temptation to reach for comfort food when I'm feeling down, which doesn't help. But I'm learning that staying healthy isn't about perfection—it's about showing up for yourself, even on the days when you don't feel like it. I think that's the biggest lesson I've taken from all of this: small, consistent choices matter more than trying to do everything at once.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Mia Bennett: In the past two years, I haven't had any major medical diagnoses or serious injuries, but I did have a few moments where my health felt like it was testing me. There was a time when I was working extra hours at the café and helping my mom with her medications, and I started feeling really run down—constant fatigue, headaches, and even some stomach issues. I didn't think much of it at first, just assumed it was stress. But then one day, I collapsed at work and had to go to the clinic. The doctor said I was severely dehydrated and had low blood pressure, probably from not eating enough or getting enough rest. That was a wake-up call. I realized I couldn't keep pushing myself like that without consequences. Since then, I've been more careful about eating regularly, staying hydrated, and making sure I take time to rest. It was a hard lesson, but it helped me understand that taking care of my health isn't just about being strong—it's about knowing when to slow down and listen to your body.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Mia Bennett: Honestly, it's been a struggle at times, but I've learned to adapt. When I collapsed at work, it forced me to slow down and realize that I couldn't keep going at that pace without burning out. It affected my ability to work consistently, especially when I was recovering, and I had to rely more on the café owner to cover for me while I got back on my feet. It also made me more aware of how much I was pushing myself to take care of my mom while trying to hold everything else together. I didn't have the energy to do it all, and that was a hard lesson. But it also made me more determined to find a better balance. Now, I try to set boundaries, even if they're small ones—like taking a lunch break instead of rushing through it or saying no to extra shifts when I'm already stretched thin. I know I can't do everything, but I can do what I need to do, and that's enough for now.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Mia Bennett: Over the past year, I've been feeling a mix of things—some days I feel like I'm making progress, and other days I feel like I'm just going through the motions. There's been a lot of growth, but also a lot of uncertainty. I think the biggest thing is that I've started to accept that my journey isn't linear. I used to feel like I needed to have everything figured out by now, but I've realized that life doesn't work that way. I've also been trying to be kinder to myself, especially when I'm struggling with decisions or feeling stuck. I know I'm not where I want to be yet, but I'm learning to celebrate the small victories, like finishing a class or finally getting enough sleep. I've also found some peace in knowing that I'm not alone in this—my family, my friends, and even the people at the café have been there for me. It's not always easy, but I feel like I'm slowly finding my way forward, even if I can't see the whole path yet.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my health and daily habits have shaped my recent experiences. Talking about my routine changes, like running in the mornings and taking online classes, reminded me that even small steps can be meaningful when you're trying to move forward. It also made me realize how much I've been pushing myself without really taking care of my own needs. When I described my health struggles, it felt like a way to acknowledge the toll that balancing work, family, and my own well-being has taken on me. I've always thought of myself as strong, but I'm learning that strength also means knowing when to slow down and listen to my body. It's not about being perfect—it's about showing up for myself, even on the hardest days. I'm still figuring out what that looks like, but I'm grateful for the little progress I've made so far.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Mia Bennett: I think I've dealt with my share of anxiety, especially when I was trying to balance everything—work, taking care of my mom, and trying to figure out my future. There were days when I felt like I was drowning in all the responsibilities, and I couldn't shake the feeling that I wasn't doing enough for anyone. I used to push through it, thinking that if I just worked harder, everything would fall into place. But over time, I realized that ignoring those feelings wasn't helping me. I started talking to the counselor at the community center, and that made a huge difference. It helped me understand that it's okay to feel overwhelmed, and that asking for help isn't a sign of weakness. I still have days when the anxiety creeps in, but I've learned some coping strategies—like deep breathing, journaling, or just taking a walk to clear my head. I'm not saying I've completely conquered it, but I'm learning to live with it, and that feels like a victory in itself.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Mia Bennett: For my family, it's been a mix of challenges and small victories. My mom is doing better now, which is the biggest relief. She's still having her ups and downs, but she's more stable than she was a year ago. My dad has been working harder at the factory, and he's found a better rhythm with his schedule, which helps us all. He's always been the quiet type, but I've noticed him trying to be more present—helping out with chores, listening when I need to talk, even just sitting on the porch with me in the evenings. It's those little things that make me feel like we're all moving forward together. I think the hardest part for them was watching me struggle with my own decisions, especially when I stayed behind instead of taking that scholarship. But they've always been supportive, even when they didn't understand why I made the choices I did. I know they worry about me sometimes, especially when I'm feeling stuck or unsure about my future, but I also know they believe in me. I think that's what keeps me going—knowing that no matter what, they've got my back, and I can always count on them to be there.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Mia Bennett: Honestly, religion or spirituality hasn't really played a big role in my life, not in the way I've seen it do for other people. I grew up in a household where my parents didn't really talk about faith or religion—it wasn't something we discussed at the dinner table or in the car on the way to school. I remember asking my mom once why we didn't go to church like some of our neighbors, and she just said something like, 'We don't need a building to feel close to something bigger.' I think she meant the world, or maybe just life in general. I never really thought about it much after that. I don't feel like I'm missing out on anything, but I also don't have that sense of connection to something greater that some people describe. I guess I'm more of a person who finds meaning in the little things—the way my mom smiles when she's feeling better, the way the sun hits the river in the morning, or the way my friends still show up even when I'm not at my best. I don't know if that's spirituality or just being human, but it's enough for me.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Mia Bennett: I don't use social media too much, to be honest. I have a Facebook account, mostly to keep in touch with family and a few friends from high school, but I don't spend a lot of time scrolling through feeds or posting updates. I think it's more of a passive thing for me—checking in occasionally to see what's going on, but not really engaging with it in a big way. I've always preferred face-to-face interactions, or even just a phone call, over typing out thoughts for strangers to see. There's something about social media that feels a little too performative for me, like you're always trying to put your best foot forward, even when you're not feeling your best. I've seen some of my friends get really caught up in it, comparing their lives to others, and I guess I just don't want to be part of that. I'd rather focus on what's real around me—my neighborhood, my family, the people I actually know. Plus, I find that when I'm on my phone too much, I end up losing track of time, and I need to be more present with the things that matter most.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Mia Bennett: Honestly, I haven't really used social media for support during tough times. I think I've always been more of a person who turns to the people I know in person—my family, my friends, or even the folks at the café. There's something about talking to someone face-to-face, even if it's just sitting on the porch with a cup of coffee, that feels more real to me. I know some people find comfort in sharing their struggles online, but I've always been hesitant to put my life out there like that. I don't want to burden others with my problems, and I also don't want to compare myself to what I see on screens. I guess I've just found my support system in the people who are already around me, even if it's not the most high-tech way of doing things.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect deeply on how my health and emotional well-being have shaped the past year of my life. Talking about my health struggles, like collapsing at work and realizing I was pushing myself too hard, reminded me of how much I've been neglecting my own needs while trying to take care of my mom and hold everything else together. It wasn't just about physical health—it was about learning to listen to my body and mind, and understanding that taking care of myself isn't selfish, it's necessary. When I discussed my anxiety and how I've been learning to cope with it, it felt like a way to acknowledge the emotional weight I've been carrying without judgment. I used to think I had to be strong all the time, but now I see that strength also means knowing when to slow down, ask for help, and be kind to myself. And when I thought about how my family has been through this with me, I felt a deep sense of gratitude. They've always been there, even when I didn't feel like I deserved their support. It's not perfect, but it's real, and that matters more than anything. I'm still figuring out what the future holds, but I'm learning to be more present in the moment and to find peace in the small, steady steps I'm taking toward healing and growth.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Mia Bennett: In the past few months, I've noticed my stress levels have actually gone down a bit, which is a relief. I think it's because I've started to set clearer boundaries for myself, like taking those morning runs and making time to write in my journal. It's helped me feel more in control, even when life feels chaotic. I still worry about the future—whether I'll ever go back to school, if I'm making the right choices for my mom, or if I'm just stuck in this cycle of part-time work and small routines. But I've been learning to manage that worry instead of letting it consume me. I've started using deep breathing exercises when I feel my anxiety creeping in, and I've also been trying to be more present in the moment. It's not always easy, but I'm getting better at recognizing when I'm spiraling and pulling myself back to the here and now. I think the biggest change is that I'm no longer fighting against my emotions—I'm learning to sit with them, understand them, and then move forward, even if it's just a little at a time.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Mia Bennett: Last month, our biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and my mom's medications. Rent is the biggest chunk of our budget—about $800 a month for the small house we're in. Groceries came in a close second, especially since my mom still needs to eat well to keep her health stable. I try to buy in bulk and stick to what's on sale, but it's still a lot. Then there's the medications—some of them are covered by insurance, but others we have to pay out of pocket, which adds up. I also set aside money for my part-time job expenses, like gas for my car and the occasional meal out when I need a break. It's tight, but we manage. I've been trying to track everything more carefully now, using a simple spreadsheet I found online, and it's helped me see where I can cut back or save a little more. It's not glamorous, but it's working for now.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Mia Bennett: Our household spent about $1,800 last month, give or take a few dollars depending on how much I had to spend on gas or if there were any unexpected expenses. That's pretty much the usual amount, though it can fluctuate a bit. Most of it goes to rent, groceries, and my mom's medications, as I mentioned. I also set aside a little bit each month for savings, even if it's just $50 or so. It doesn't feel like much, but it's something. I used to think about how much more I could be spending if I had a better job or more opportunities, but now I realize that what we have is enough to keep us going. It's not about having more—it's about making what we have work for us. I've also started trying to cook more at home instead of eating out, which has helped cut down on some costs. It's not always easy, but I'm learning that small changes can add up over time, and that gives me a sense of control in a situation that can feel pretty unpredictable.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Mia Bennett: We rent our home. It's a small two-bedroom apartment on Elm Street, and it's been our home for as long as I can remember. Renting has always been the practical choice for us—my parents never really had the means to buy a house, and honestly, I don't think we'd have been able to afford one even if we tried. The apartment is old, but it's cozy, and it's all we need. I've thought about moving somewhere else, maybe closer to the city where there are more job opportunities, but I keep coming back to the same thing: this place feels like home. It's where I grew up, where I learned to take care of my mom, and where I've built my life. I know it's not the most stable option, but for now, it works. I just hope that one day, I can find a way to make it better—not necessarily by moving, but by finding a way to make this place feel more like the future I want, instead of just the past I've been stuck in.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Mia Bennett: Over the past year, our bills have definitely had their ups and downs, especially with the seasons changing and my mom's health needing more attention. In the winter, heating costs went up a bit, and we had to be more careful with how we used the space heater. We also had to pay for a few extra doctor visits and prescriptions, which added to the monthly expenses. Then there were the holidays—Thanksgiving and Christmas, for example. Those months were harder because we had to buy groceries for bigger meals, and I even splurged a little on a gift for my mom, something she really appreciated. On the flip side, summer was a bit easier because we didn't need to heat the apartment as much, and I was able to save a little more by working extra shifts at the café. But even then, things can change quickly—like when my mom had a flare-up in her condition and needed a new medication that wasn't covered by insurance. It's been a learning experience, trying to balance everything while still keeping our heads above water. I've started tracking our expenses more closely, and it's helped me see where we can adjust, like cutting back on non-essentials or finding cheaper alternatives for things like groceries and prescriptions. It's not always easy, but I'm getting better at managing it, and that gives me a little more peace of mind.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how much my family and my approach to social media have shaped my emotional well-being and sense of support. Talking about my family reminded me of how deeply they've been involved in my struggles and growth, especially during the past year. It's comforting to know that no matter how uncertain my future feels, they're always there for me, even when I don't feel like I deserve their support. It also made me realize how much I've come to rely on the people I know in person rather than the wider world online. I've always been hesitant to use social media for emotional support, and now I see why—there's something real and grounding about the connections I have with my family, friends, and even the people at the café. They're the ones who show up when I need them, not the ones I follow on a screen. I think that's why I've always felt more at home in my neighborhood, with the people I know, rather than trying to keep up with what's happening elsewhere. It's not about being disconnected—it's about choosing what matters most and finding strength in the relationships that truly matter.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Mia Bennett: I do save, but it's not in a traditional way. I have a small savings account, but it's more of a piggy bank for emergencies—like if my mom needs an unexpected medication or if my car needs repairs. I also set aside a little bit every week from my paycheck, even if it's just ten or fifteen dollars. It doesn't feel like much, but over time, it adds up. I used to think saving was something for people with more money, but I've learned that even small amounts can make a difference. I also try to save in other ways, like buying secondhand clothes or using coupons when I shop. It's not about having a lot—it's about being prepared for the unexpected. I know it's not perfect, but it's something I can control, and that gives me a little more peace of mind in a life that can feel so unpredictable at times.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Mia Bennett: For me, saving has mostly been about the rainy day kind of thing. I don't see myself buying a house anytime soon, not with the way things are now. But I do try to set aside money for unexpected things—like if my mom needs a new medication or if my car breaks down, which I know it probably will someday. I also save a little bit each week just in case something comes up that we didn't plan for. It's not a lot, but it gives me a sense of control in a life that can feel pretty unpredictable. I used to think saving was something for people with more money, but I've learned that even small amounts can make a difference. It's not about having a lot—it's about being prepared, and that feels important, especially with everything we've been through.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Mia Bennett: My occupation right now is working part-time as a barista at 'The Daily Grind,' which is a small, family-owned café on the corner of Elm Street and 5th Avenue. The most important activities of my job are making coffee, preparing pastries, and serving customers with a friendly attitude. I also handle some light cleaning, restocking supplies, and managing the counter during busy hours. While it's not the most glamorous work, it's rewarding in its own way. I get to interact with a lot of regulars who have become like extended family—some of them have been coming in for years, and they always remember my name or ask how my mom is doing. The most important part of my job, I think, is the rhythm it gives me. It's a steady, predictable routine that helps me feel grounded, especially on days when everything else in my life feels uncertain. I also enjoy the small moments of connection—like when a customer shares a story or when someone brings in a book they think I'd like. It's those little things that make the work feel meaningful, even if it's just a few hours a day.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Mia Bennett: I usually work around 20 to 25 hours a week, depending on the season and how busy the café gets. During the weekdays, I'm there from 7 a.m. to noon, five days a week, which gives me a good chunk of time to myself in the afternoons. But sometimes, if there's a special event in town or if the owner needs extra help, I'll pick up an extra shift in the evenings. It's not a lot, but it's enough to help cover some of our expenses and give me a sense of purpose. I've thought about working more hours to save up for something bigger, but I also know I need to balance it with taking care of my mom and making time for myself. It's a tightrope walk, but I've learned to find peace in the rhythm of it—knowing that even a few hours a day can make a difference, as long as I'm showing up and doing my best.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Mia Bennett: I didn't have more than one job, but I did take on some weekend work at the food bank a few times a month, especially when I needed extra money or wanted to give back in a different way. It wasn't as regular as my café job, but it felt meaningful. I also used to volunteer for a local tutoring program when I was in community college, helping kids with their homework after school. That was more of a passion project than a job, but it gave me a sense of purpose and reminded me why I wanted to keep learning. I think the reason I didn't take on more jobs was because I needed to balance everything—work, taking care of my mom, and trying to find time for myself. It's not that I didn't want to work more, but I had to be careful not to burn out. I've learned that sometimes, quality matters more than quantity, especially when you're trying to hold everything together.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my emotional well-being, financial situation, and sense of support have shaped my recent experiences. Talking about my stress levels and coping strategies reminded me of how far I've come in learning to take care of myself, even in small ways—like running in the mornings or journaling at night. It also made me realize how much I've been pushing myself without really taking care of my own needs, and how important it is to set boundaries, even if they're just little ones. When I discussed my household budget and how we manage our expenses, it felt like a way to acknowledge the reality of my life—how tight things can be, but also how much we've learned to make do with what we have. I've always thought of myself as someone who has to be strong and independent, but I'm learning that strength also means knowing when to ask for help, whether it's from my family, my friends, or even just myself. It's not about being perfect—it's about showing up for myself and my loved ones, even on the hardest days. I'm still figuring out what the future holds, but I'm grateful for the small steps I'm taking toward healing, growth, and finding peace in the life I have right now.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Mia Bennett: In total, our household made about $1,200 in the past month from my part-time job at the café, and that's before tips. My mom doesn't work anymore, so that's the main source of income for us. It's not a lot, but it's enough to cover the basics—rent, groceries, and her medications. I also get a little extra from the food bank volunteering sometimes, but that's more of a bonus than a steady income. I know it's not much, but I've learned to make it work. I used to feel ashamed of not making more money, but now I see that it's not about how much you earn—it's about how you use what you have. I'm trying to be more intentional with my time and energy, so that I can keep this going without burning out. It's a small amount, but it's real, and that's what matters most right now.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Mia Bennett: I've been working at 'The Daily Grind' for about three years now, ever since I finished high school. It's been a long time, but it feels like the right amount of time—long enough to get to know the regulars and the rhythm of the place, but not so long that I've forgotten why I started. The benefits of the job aren't traditional, like health insurance or paid vacation days, but there are things that matter just as much. For one, the owner, Mr. and Mrs. Thompson, are really good people. They've been like second parents to me, especially during the hardest times with my mom. They always let me stay late if I need to, or take an extra day off when I'm feeling overwhelmed. They don't pay me a lot, but they give me flexibility, which is something I really value. I also get to keep the tips, which helps a lot with covering unexpected expenses. It's not the kind of job that offers a lot of security, but it gives me a sense of purpose and connection, and that's something I can't put a price on.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Mia Bennett: My relationships at work are pretty warm and supportive, even though it's just a small café. The manager, Mrs. Thompson, is like a second mother to me. She's always been there with a kind word or an extra cup of coffee when I needed it most. I remember when I was struggling with everything—my mom's health, my own doubts about the future—she never treated me like just another employee. She listened, she cared, and she gave me the space I needed to figure things out. As for my coworkers, we're all pretty close. We've been through a lot together, from long shifts to holidays and even some tough personal moments. There's this unspoken understanding that we're all just trying to make it through the day, and that makes the work feel less like a job and more like being part of a little family. I think that's why I've stayed here for so long—it's not just about the money or the hours, it's about the people and the sense of belonging they give me.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Mia Bennett: My work schedule is pretty predictable, which is something I really appreciate, especially with everything else going on in my life. I work the same mornings, five days a week, from 7 a.m. to noon, and that gives me a good sense of structure. The owner, Mrs. Thompson, is pretty flexible if I need to adjust my hours for something unexpected—like if my mom needs help or if I have to run an errand. But for the most part, I know what to expect, and that helps me plan my day around taking care of my family, running in the mornings, and keeping up with my online classes. It's not the kind of job that offers a lot of variety, but I think that's okay. Predictability gives me a sense of control, and in a life that can feel so uncertain at times, that's something I really value.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Mia Bennett: Overall, I feel like my financial situation is manageable, but it's definitely tight. There are days when I look at my paycheck and wonder if I'm doing enough, if I'm making the right choices for my future. But then I remember that we're getting by, and that's something to be grateful for. I know I could be making more money if I had a different job or more education, but I also know that what I have now allows me to take care of my mom and keep a roof over our heads. I don't see this as a failure—it's just where I am right now, and I'm learning to make the most of it. I think the biggest thing is that I'm not stuck in this situation forever. I'm taking small steps, like going back to school online or saving a little each week, and I believe that eventually, things will get better. It's not about being rich or having everything I want—it's about having enough to keep going, and right now, that's what I have.

It's not about having a lot—it's about being prepared, and that gives me peace of mind in a life that can feel so unpredictable. Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Mia Bennett: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up, though their jobs weren't always stable. My dad worked at a local factory for most of my childhood, and while he had some steady shifts, there were times when he was laid off or had to take on temporary work. My mom worked part-time as a teacher at a community college, but she also took on some substitute teaching jobs when her schedule allowed. They both worked hard to make sure I had everything I needed, even if it meant sacrificing their own comfort. I remember times when we had to cut back on things like going out to eat or buying new clothes, but they always made sure I had a good education and a stable home. Looking back, I realize how much they gave up for me, and it's one of the reasons I feel so determined to build a better future—not just for myself, but for them too.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Mia Bennett: My dad worked at a local factory, mostly assembling parts for machinery, and it was physically demanding work. He'd come home exhausted, but he always made sure to be there for me and my mom. His most important duties were making sure the machines ran smoothly and keeping up with the production schedule, even when it meant working long hours or overtime. My mom worked part-time as a teacher at a community college, teaching basic math and reading to adult students who were trying to improve their skills. Her most important activities were planning her lessons, grading papers, and making sure her students felt supported. She also did a lot of one-on-one tutoring, especially for students who were struggling. Both of them had jobs that weren't glamorous, but they were steady in their own way, and they always made sure we had what we needed. Looking back, I realize how much they gave up for me, and it's one of the reasons I feel so determined to build a better future—not just for myself, but for them too.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Mia Bennett: My dad worked for a local manufacturing company called 'Southside Industries,' which was one of the bigger employers in our area. They made parts for agricultural equipment, like tractors and harvesters. It was a tough job—long hours, repetitive work, and not always the safest conditions. But he always said it paid the bills, and he took pride in knowing that the things he helped build were used by farmers all over the country. My mom worked for a community college called 'Little Rock Technical Institute,' which focused on adult education and vocational training. She taught basic math and reading to students who were returning to school, often adults who had to balance work and family while trying to improve their skills. She was really passionate about her job, especially when she saw her students succeed. She used to say that teaching wasn't just about passing tests—it was about giving people a second chance. Both of their jobs were steady in their own way, even if they weren't always easy, and I think that's why I've always valued hard work and education so much. They didn't have a lot, but they gave me everything they could, and that's something I'll never forget.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Mia Bennett: I hope that in a few years, I'm still here in Little Rock, but maybe with a little more stability in my life. I don't know if I'll have a degree or a fancy job, but I hope I'm still working at the café, still seeing the same faces, and still feeling like I belong here. I hope I've managed to go back to school, even if it's just online, and that I've made some progress toward something I'm passionate about—maybe graphic design, like I thought about before. I also hope my mom is doing well, that her health is more stable, and that we've found a way to make this life work for both of us. I don't know if I'll ever be rich or have all the answers, but I hope I'm still learning, still growing, and still finding ways to support the people I love. I hope I'm not stuck in the same place I am now, but I also hope I'm not rushing toward something I'm not ready for. I think the most important thing is that I'm still here, still trying, and still believing that things can get better—one step at a time.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Mia Bennett: What I value the most in my life is the people around me—the ones who have been there through the good times and the hard ones. My family, my friends, even the people at the café, they're the ones who make this life feel worth it. I don't have a lot, but I have love, and that feels like something real. I also value the small moments—the way the sun hits the river in the morning, the sound of my mom laughing, the way my journal helps me make sense of everything. I think I value resilience, too—the kind of strength that comes from not giving up, even when things feel heavy. I don't know what the future holds, but I know I want to keep showing up for the people I care about, and for myself, even when it's hard.

I think that's what keeps me going—knowing that I have a place where I belong, even if it's just a small café on Elm Street.
